Introduction.content:
Juma was twelve years old and lived in a dusty little town.

He had the most beautiful shadow in the world: tall, straight, and always dancing when he walked.

Every afternoon, children followed him just to watch his shadow play on the walls.

Juma was proud of it.

One day, a rich stranger in a shiny car stopped beside him.

‚ÄúI will give you one million shillings for your shadow,‚Äù the man said.

Juma laughed‚Ä¶ then stopped laughing.

One million was a lot of money.

Chapter 1.content:
The stranger opened a black suitcase full of crisp notes.

Juma‚Äôs eyes became big.

He thought: With this money Mama can stop washing clothes. We can fix the roof. I can go to school.

He said, ‚ÄúOkay. Take my shadow.‚Äù

The man smiled, took out silver scissors, and cut the shadow from Juma‚Äôs feet.

It hurt like ice.

![Man cutting shadow with silver scissors](https://picsum.photos/seed/shadow-cut-scissors/800/600)

The shadow rolled up like black cloth and went into the suitcase.

The car drove away.

Chapter 2.content:
At first everyone was happy.

Mama bought a new roof. Juma wore shoes for the first time.

But soon strange things started.

- Dogs barked at him
- Birds flew away scared
- His own mother sometimes looked past him like he was not there

At noon, when shadows are shortest, Juma disappeared completely.

![Boy with no shadow at noon](https://picsum.photos/seed/juma-no-shadow-noon/800/600)

He felt cold even in the sun.

Chapter 3.content:
The rich man took Juma‚Äôs shadow to the city.

He put it in a glass box in the biggest mall.

Ticket: 500 shillings to see ‚ÄúThe Perfect Dancing Shadow‚Äù.

People came from everywhere. The shadow danced day and night under bright lights.

It became more famous than any singer.

But every night, the shadow pressed its hands against the glass and cried silent tears.

![Shadow crying inside glass box](https://picsum.photos/seed/shadow-cry-glass/800/600)

Chapter 4.content:
Juma saved bus money for months.

He travelled to the city alone.

When he reached the mall, he stood in front of the glass box.

The shadow saw him and started jumping with joy.

Juma pressed his hand on the glass. The shadow pressed back.

Juma whispered, ‚ÄúI am sorry. I will bring you home.‚Äù

![Boy and shadow touching through glass](https://picsum.photos/seed/boy-shadow-glass/800/800/600)

Chapter 5.content:
That night Juma waited until the mall closed.

He broke the glass with a stone.

The shadow ran to him and wrapped around his feet like a warm blanket.

Juma felt whole again.

The million shillings? He left every coin on the floor.

He only wanted his shadow back.

![Shadow hugging boy‚Äôs feet](https://picsum.photos/seed/shadow-hug-feet/800/600)

Conclusion.content:
Juma returned to his town poorer but warmer.

His shadow danced bigger and happier than ever.

Now when children ask, ‚ÄúWhy is your shadow the best?‚Äù

Juma smiles and answers:

‚ÄúBecause it travelled the world and chose to come home.‚Äù

And every afternoon, the shadow waves at the sky as if saying thank you for letting it go and thank you for bringing it back.

The end.

![Boy and happy shadow dancing together](https://picsum.photos/seed/juma-happy-dance/800/600)
